questions.text: Which of the following branches of chemistry involves separating, identifying and determining the relative amount of a sample of matter?
questions.explanation: Analytical chemistry deals with separating, identifying, and quantifying matter.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation: 1 liter is equivalent to 1 cubic decimeter (1L = 1dm³).

questions.text: A piece of silver metal weighing 160 g is placed in a graduated cylinder containing 220 ml of water. The volume of water now reads 240 ml. What is the density of the silver metal?
questions.explanation: The volume displaced is 240 ml - 220 ml = 20 ml. The density is mass/volume = 160 g / 20 ml = 8.0 g/ml.

questions.text: What is the first step of the scientific method?
options: C. Predicting the result of an experiment
questions.explanation: The first step is making observations about the problem or phenomenon.

questions.text: A student uses a digital balance (± 0.01), a thermometer (± 0.02), a measuring cylinder (± 0.03) and a beaker (± 0.04) during an experiment. Which of the above instruments is more precise?
questions.explanation: The digital balance is the most precise, with the smallest margin of error.

questions.text: Which of the following postulates of Dalton’s atomic theory is disproved by the modern atomic theory?
options: A. Atoms combine in small whole numbers to form compounds
B. Elements are made up of small particles called atoms
C. Atoms of different elements have different masses and size
D. All atoms of the same elements are identical and have the same mass
questions.explanation: The modern atomic theory shows that atoms of the same element can have different masses, called isotopes.

questions.text: The main purpose of Robert Millikan’s oil drop experiment is to determine
options: A. The ratio of mass of electron to charge of electron
C. The magnitude of charge of electron
questions.explanation: Millikan's experiment determined the charge of the electron.

questions.text: Pb has an average atomic mass of 207.19 amu. The three major isotopes of Pb-206 (205.98 amu), Pb-207 (206.98 amu) and Pb-208 (207.98 amu). If the isotopes of Pb-207 and Pb-208 are present in equal amounts, what is the percent abundance of Pb-206, Pb-207 and Pb-208 respectively?
questions.explanation: Using the average atomic mass and isotope data, the correct percentages are 19.34% for Pb-206, 40.33% for Pb-207, and 40.33% for Pb-208.

questions.text: Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum is capable of inducing electron transition with the greatest energy?
questions.explanation: Violet light has the shortest wavelength and the highest energy.

questions.text: What is the wavelength of the yellow sodium emission, which has a frequency of 5.09 x 10^14 s^-1? (C = 3 x 10^8 m/s)
questions.explanation: Using the formula λ = c / f, the wavelength λ = (3 x 10^8 m/s) / (5.09 x 10^14 s^-1) = 589 nm.

questions.text: What are the possible values of the azimuthal quantum number for an electron in the 4f sub shell?
questions.explanation: For the 4f sub shell, the possible values of the azimuthal quantum number (l) are 3.

questions.text: How many 3d electrons are present in the ground state of 52Cr?
questions.explanation: In the ground state, chromium (Cr) has 5 electrons in the 3d orbital.

questions.text: All of the following properties of an element increase across a period, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Atomic size decreases across a period, while electron affinity, electronegativity, and ionization energy increase.

questions.text: All of the following are properties of ionic compounds in the solid phase, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Ionic compounds in the solid phase do not conduct electricity because their ions are not free to move.

questions.text: Which of the following ionic compounds has the highest lattice energy?
questions.explanation: MgO has the highest lattice energy due to the small size and high charge of Mg2+ and O2- ions.

questions.text: Which one of the substances contains ionic, covalent and dative bonds between their atoms?
questions.explanation: NH4CN contains ionic bonds between NH4+ and CN-, covalent bonds within NH4+ and CN-, and a dative bond in NH4+.

questions.text: All of the following molecules are an example of polar covalent compounds, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: CS2 is a nonpolar molecule, while the others are polar covalent.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a non-polar molecule with individual bonds that are polar?
questions.explanation: CO2 is a linear molecule, and despite having polar bonds, it is nonpolar due to its symmetrical shape.

questions.text: Which bond between the following groups of elements will be the most polar?
questions.explanation: S-F is the most polar because the electronegativity difference between sulfur and fluorine is the greatest.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the geometry of ICl4-?
questions.explanation: The geometry of ICl4- is square planar due to its electron cloud arrangement.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT true of metallic bonding?
options: A. It gives rise to excellent electrical conductivity
B. Electrons are free to move throughout the structure
C. The strength of metallic bonds increases down a group
D. The strength of metallic bonding affects the boiling points of metals
questions.explanation: The strength of metallic bonds generally decreases as you move down a group due to the increasing size of atoms and distance between nuclei and electrons.

questions.text: What type of hybridization is used by carbon in C2H2 (acetylene)?
questions.explanation: In acetylene (C2H2), each carbon atom is sp hybridized due to the formation of a triple bond between the two carbon atoms.

questions.text: Which molecule listed below has two sigma (σ) and two pi (π) bonds?
questions.explanation: N2F2 has two sigma and two pi bonds due to the double bonds between the nitrogen atoms and the single bonds with the fluorine atoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct rate equation for the given elementary reaction?
options: B. A + B + C → P, Rate = K[A][C]
D. A + B → P, Rate = K[A][B]
questions.explanation: For an elementary reaction, the rate law follows the stoichiometry, so the rate equation for A + B → P is Rate = K[A][B].

questions.text: Given the reaction: 2NO (g) + O2 (g) → 2NO2 (g), Rate = K[NO]2[O]. Which of the following is true if the pressure of NO is doubled?
options: A. The reaction rate increases by a factor of four
B. The reaction rate increases by a factor of two
C. The reaction rate increases by a factor of three
D. The reaction rate increases by a factor of eight
questions.explanation: Since the rate law is second order with respect to NO, doubling the concentration of NO will increase the rate by a factor of 2^2 = 4.

questions.text: Which conditions generally will increase the rate of a chemical reaction?
options: A. Decreasing temperature and increasing concentration of the reactants.
B. Decreasing temperature and decreasing concentration of the reactants.
C. Increasing temperature and increasing concentration of the reactants.
D. Increasing temperature and decreasing concentration of the reactants.
questions.explanation: Increasing both temperature and concentration of reactants typically increases the rate of a chemical reaction.

questions.text: What is the value of rate constant (K) for first order reaction with half-life 3000 second?
questions.explanation: For a first-order reaction, the half-life (t½) is related to the rate constant by the equation t½ = 0.693 / K. Solving for K gives a value of 2.31 x 10−4 s−1.

questions.text: For a certain reaction, rate = k [A], the rate when [A] = 0.60 M, if the rate is 0.020 M/s when [A] = 1.0 M. What is the rate when [A] = 0.60 M?
questions.explanation: Since the rate is directly proportional to [A], the rate when [A] = 0.60 M is (0.60/1.0) × 0.020 M/s = 0.012 M/s.

questions.text: Which of the following is a termolecular reaction?
questions.explanation: A termolecular reaction involves three reactants. The reaction N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3 is termolecular because it involves four molecules of reactants.

questions.text: Which one of the following indicates the correct expression for the equilibrium constant (K)? PCl5 (s) ⇌ PCl3 (l) + Cl2 (g)
questions.explanation: The equilibrium expression only includes the concentrations of gases and aqueous species. The solid PCl5 does not appear in the expression, so the correct expression is K = [Cl2].

questions.text: One of the following is true about acid and base?
options: A. Base is the substance when dissolved in water increases the [H3O+]
B. Acid is the substance when dissolved in water increases the [OH᎗]
questions.explanation: The Bronsted-Lowry definition states that bases are proton acceptors.

questions.text: What are the products in the self-ionization of water molecules?
questions.explanation: Water self-ionizes to form hydronium (H3O+) and hydroxide (OH᎗) ions.

questions.text: The conjugate base of H3O+ is:
questions.explanation: When H3O+ donates a proton, it forms its conjugate base, H2O.

questions.text: Given the reaction: H2PO− + H2O ⇌ H3O+ + HPO2−. Which of the following represents a conjugate acid-base pair?
questions.explanation: H2PO− donates a proton to form HPO2−, making them a conjugate acid-base pair.

questions.text: The POH of a 0.00008 M NaOH aqueous solution is:
questions.explanation: POH = -log[OH-], so POH = -log(0.00008) ≈ 4.1.

questions.text: What is the PH of an aqueous solution in which [OH᎗] = 10000 [H3O+] at 25 ℃?
questions.explanation: Since the concentration of OH᎗ is much higher, the solution is basic, and pH > 7.

questions.text: What is the percent dissociation in 1M solution of HF containing the concentration of [H3O+] = 2.7 × 10−2 M?
The concentration of H3O+ and OH− respectively with POH = 3 at 25°C are:
questions.explanation: Using the relationship pOH + pH = 14, we can calculate the concentration of H3O+ and OH−.

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of 1.0 M HCl but not a property of 1.0 M CH3COOH?
options: B. Has a PH less than 7
questions.explanation: HCl ionizes completely in solution, unlike CH3COOH which is a weak acid.

questions.text: What is the PH and POH of an aqueous solution at 25°C if [H3O+] = 0.0004 M respectively?
questions.explanation: pH = -log[H3O+] = 3.4 and pOH = 14 - pH = 10.6.

questions.text: What is the effect if 0.3 M of CH3COONa is added into aqueous solution of 0.2 M CH3COOH?
options: B. The concentration H3O+ will increase
C. The equilibrium shifts to the left
questions.explanation: Adding CH3COONa (a salt of the conjugate base) to CH3COOH (a weak acid) shifts the equilibrium to the left, decreasing the acidity.

questions.text: How is a buffer solution prepared?
options: A. By mixing a weak acid and a strong acid
B. By mixing a strong base and its conjugate acid
C. By mixing a strong acid and its conjugate base
D. By mixing a weak acid and its conjugate base
questions.explanation: A buffer solution is typically prepared by mixing a weak acid and its conjugate base.

questions.text: The POH of an aqueous solution which is created by adding 0.5 M NH3 and 0.5 M NH4Cl (Kb NH3 = 1.8x10−5)
questions.explanation: The POH is calculated based on the Kb of NH3 and the concentrations of NH3 and NH4Cl, giving a value of 10.26.

questions.text: In which of the following combination buffer solution possibly formed?
questions.explanation: CH3COOH (a weak acid) and CH3COONa (its conjugate base) form a buffer solution.

questions.text: The Ka of benzoic acid is 6.30 x 10−5. What is the pH of a buffer prepared by combining 50 ml of 1.0 M potassium benzoate and 50 ml of 1.0 M benzoic acid?
questions.explanation: Using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, the pH of the buffer is found to be approximately 4.2.

questions.text: Which of the following is a basic salt?
questions.explanation: HCOOK (potassium formate) is the salt of a weak acid and a strong base, making it basic.

questions.text: Which one of the following hydrolysis of salt results in an acidic solution?
options: A. Weak acid and strong base
B. Weak base and strong acid
C. Strong acid and strong base
D. Weak acid and salt of the weak acid
questions.explanation: The hydrolysis of a weak base with a strong acid results in an acidic solution.

questions.text: The acid-base indicator methyl orange has a Ka of 1 x 10−6. Its acidic form is red while its basic form is yellow. If methyl orange is added to a solution with a pH = 5, the color will be;
questions.explanation: At pH = 5, methyl orange will be orange, as it lies between the red and yellow forms.

questions.text: Which of the following titrations will have an equivalence point at a pH > 7?
options: A. Weak acid with weak base
B. Weak acid with strong base
C. Strong acid with weak base
D. Strong acid with strong base
questions.explanation: The equivalence point for a weak acid and strong base titration is above pH 7.

questions.text: What volume of 0.2 M KOH is required to neutralize completely 50 mL of 1.5 M H2SO4?
questions.explanation: Using stoichiometry, 0.2 M KOH requires 250 mL to neutralize 50 mL of 1.5 M H2SO4.

questions.text: What is the normality of 0.3 M solution of Al2(SO4)3?
questions.explanation: Normality = Molarity × equivalent factor, where Al2(SO4)3 has an equivalent factor of 3, so normality is 0.9.

questions.text: What is the molarity from complete ionization of 1.5N H2SO4?
questions.explanation: Molarity = Normality / number of equivalents, so 1.5 N H2SO4 gives 2 M.

questions.text: Which of the following can conduct electricity?
questions.explanation: Salt solutions conduct electricity because they contain ions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about electrolytic cells?
options: B. Convert chemical to electrical energy
C. Oxidation occurs at the anode
D. Redox reaction takes place in the cells
questions.explanation: Electrolytic cells convert electrical energy to chemical energy, not the other way around.

questions.text: The oxidation number of phosphorous in PO3− is;
questions.explanation: In PO3−, the oxidation number of phosphorus is -3.

questions.text: In the reaction H2S(aq) + I2(aq) ⇌ S(s) + 2H+(aq) + 2I−(aq) the reducing agent is:
questions.explanation: H2S is oxidized, thus acting as the reducing agent.

questions.text: One of the following is true in the electrolysis of Brine solution?
options: A. NaOH is formed in the cell
B. Cl2 is formed at cathode
C. H2 is formed at anode
D. Na is formed at cathode
questions.explanation: During the electrolysis of brine, NaOH is formed at the cathode and chlorine gas (Cl2) at the anode.

questions.text: The products for the electrolysis of molten CuCl2
options: A. O2 at anode and Cl2 at cathode
B. Cu at anode and O2 at cathode
C. Cl2 at anode and H2 at cathode
D. Cl2 at anode and Cu at cathode
questions.explanation: In the electrolysis of molten CuCl2, chlorine gas (Cl2) is produced at the anode, and copper (Cu) is deposited at the cathode.

questions.text: For the electrolysis of an aqueous solution of Na2SO4
options: A. O2 at cathode & H2 at anode are formed
B. Na at cathode & S2 at anode are formed
C. H2 at cathode & O2 at anode are formed
D. SO2 at cathode & Na at anode are formed
questions.explanation: During the electrolysis of Na2SO4 solution, hydrogen gas (H2) is formed at the cathode and oxygen gas (O2) at the anode.

questions.text: From the electrolysis of aqueous solution of AgNO3
options: A. H2 is formed at cathode
B. O2 is formed at cathode
C. Ag is formed at cathode
D. NaOH is formed in the cell
questions.explanation: During the electrolysis of AgNO3, silver (Ag) is deposited at the cathode.

questions.text: In the electrolysis of aqueous solution of copper sulphate using active copper electrode;
questions.explanation: During the electrolysis of copper sulfate solution, copper metal at the anode oxidizes to Cu2+ and releases electrons.

questions.text: What mass of Mg is formed by passing a current of 0.965 A through molten MgCl2 for a period of 100 seconds? (Molar mass of Mg = 24 g/mol, F = 96500 C)
questions.explanation: Using the equation /( m =  rac{I /cdot t /cdot M}{n /cdot F} /), the mass of magnesium formed is calculated as 0.024 g.

questions.text: What is the mass of Aluminium deposited by the electrolysis of aqueous solution Al2(SO4)3 placed in series with AgNO3 aqueous solution when 10.8 g of Ag is deposited? (Molar mass of Ag = 108, Al = 27)
questions.explanation: Using stoichiometry and Faraday's law, the mass of aluminium deposited is found to be 0.9 g.

questions.text: The volume of O2 formed at STP when OH− is oxidized by passing 100 A in 965 seconds?
questions.explanation: Using Faraday's law, the volume of oxygen gas produced is calculated as 9.6 L at STP.

questions.text: All of the following are uses of electrolysis, except;
questions.explanation: Electrolysis is not typically used to produce electricity; it is used for processes like purification and electroplating.

questions.text: All of the following are uses of electroplating, except;
options: B. Increase the beauty of the metals
C. Increase the reaction at the cathode
D. Increase the strength of the metals
questions.explanation: Electroplating is used for improving the appearance, strength, and corrosion resistance of metals, but not for increasing reactions at the cathode.

questions.text: Consider the standard voltaic cell, which answer identifies the cathode and gives the E0? Given E0red (Au+3/Au = 1.50 V, Fe+2/Fe = -0.44 V)
questions.explanation: In a standard voltaic cell, gold (Au) is the cathode with a reduction potential of 1.50 V, and the overall cell potential is 1.06 V.
